parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>The provided post does not contain a CMF number. While the absence of a CMF number is not automatically disqualifying, it suggests the post might not be directly linked to an official electoral campaign.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>The post uses the hashtag "#alegevocearatiunii" which translates to "#chooseyourvoice". While this is related to the election, it does not explicitly mention any specific parliamentary candidate by name, surname, or party affiliation.  Therefore, Article 36 (7) - a does not apply.</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>The post is a paid Facebook advertisement, inherently targeting a wide audience.  The reach estimate is ">1M", confirming its broad reach. Therefore, it addresses the wide population.</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>The hashtag "#alegevocearatiunii" ("#chooseyourvoice") encourages voters to participate in the election. However, it does not explicitly advocate for or against any particular candidate or party.  The objective seems to be general voter mobilization rather than influencing votes for a specific candidate. Therefore, Article 36 (7) - c does not clearly apply.</electoral-objective>
<journalism>The post's content is minimal.  It's a simple hashtag, not a news article or analysis. It does not provide information or analysis in a journalistic manner. Therefore, it cannot be considered journalism.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>The post does not express a personal opinion. It's a generic call to action related to voting.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>1647449636164647</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The post, while related to the election through its hashtag, lacks explicit endorsement of any candidate or party. The hashtag is a general call to vote, not a specific call to vote for a particular candidate.  The absence of a CMF number further weakens the argument for it being electoral propaganda. While the post is paid for and has a wide reach, its content is too generic to be considered electoral propaganda under Article 98 t).  The "choose your voice" message is a general encouragement to vote, not an attempt to sway votes towards a specific candidate.
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>FALSE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates/>
<responsible-party-or-group>UDMR</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police/>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
